Medieval Medicine Medieval medicine has long been thought to be of little practical use because it was heavily influenced by superstition and religious belief such as the four humors theory, astrology, and divine healing. While it is true that medicine was practiced under heavy limitations of superstition and belief, it was in fact a practical matter even then, and has been proven from skeletal evidence to have even been successful. Surgeons made treatises that described practical care, and many in the Middle Ages continued to rely on those with a practical knowledge of the human body, such as midwives.
